contextId.occurrenceNote: It is as natural for people, once they are born, to have trouble as it is for sparks to fly up from a fire. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: mankind is born for trouble, just as sparks fly upward

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "offspring" are spoken of as if they were as many as blades of grass, and probably as thriving, too. Alternate translation: "your descendants will be as many and as alive as the grass that grows" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: your offspring will be like the grass on the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares the burden of his suffering to the weight of wet sand; both can crush a person. Alternate translation: "For my anguish and calamities would be heavier than the sand on the seashore" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: For now it would be heavier than the sand of the seas

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of his friends being unfaithful to him as being like a "wadi" which is a stream that can suddenly dry up. Also, Job refers to his friends ironically here as his "brothers." Alternate translation: "But my friends are unfaithful to me. They are like a desert streambed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.glQuote: But my brothers have been as faithful to me as a desert streambed

contextId.occurrenceNote: "like streams of water that dry up." Job continues speaking of his friends being unfaithful as if they were streams that dry up. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as channels of water that pass away to nothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares how the man would sell his friend to how a person sells merchandise or wares. Alternate translation: "bargain to sell your friend for money" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: haggle over your friend like merchandise

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares his misery and trouble to that of the slave and hired man. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Like a slave ... like a hired man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares his lifetime to the quickness of a weaver's shuttle. Alternate translation: "My life goes by very quickly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: My days are swifter than a weaver's shuttle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job is describing death as being like the clouds that disappear. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As a cloud is consumed and vanishes away, so he who goes down to Sheol will come up no more

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Bildad compares the trust of the godless person to a spider's web; the slightest force will break both. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: his trust is as weak as a spider's web

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares how quickly his days are passing by to a fast runner. Alternate translation: "My days pass swiftly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: My days are swifter than a running messenger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares how quickly his days are passing by to the speed of fast boats. Alternate translation: "They pass quickly by like papyrus reed boats" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They are as fast as papyrus reed boats

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares how quickly his days are passing by to a large bird diving toward its prey. Alternate translation: "as fast as the eagle that flies down quickly to catch its food" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as fast as the eagle that swoops down on its victim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings of this simile are 1) God hunts Job like a lion hunts its prey or 2) Job is like a lion being hunted by God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: you would stalk me like a lion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The darkness of the place where the spirits of dead people go is compared to the darkness of midnight. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as dark as midnight

contextId.occurrenceNote: The light of the place where the spirits of dead people go is compared to midnight. Alternate translation: "where there is no light" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: where the light is like midnight

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zophar is comparing misery with water that flows downstream and it is gone. Alternate translation: "You would remember it, but the misery will be gone, like waters that have flowed away" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: you would remember it only like waters that have flowed away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Staggering or wandering like a drunk man represents living without purpose. Alternate translation: "he makes them live without purpose like a drunk person who staggers as he walks" or "they wander aimlessly like a drunk person who staggers back and forth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: he makes them stagger like a drunk man

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares his life to something that is decaying. He is slowly dying. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a rotten thing that wastes away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares himself to clothes that are full of holes because the moths have eaten parts of it. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a garment that moths have eaten

contextId.occurrenceNote: Like the life of a flower, a person's life is short and is easily killed. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He sprouts from the ground like a flower and is cut down

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person's short life is compared to a shadow that disappears quickly. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: he flees like a shadow and does not last

contextId.occurrenceNote: Water that has dried up from a lake or a river cannot return, and once a person dies or grows old, he cannot become young again. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As water disappears from a lake ... dries up

contextId.occurrenceNote: If it is easier in your language, you can put this phrase at the beginning of verse 18 and adjust the text accordingly. Alternate translation: "You destroy the hope of man, just like ... dust of the earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Like this, you destroy the hope of man

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares how his distress and anguish overpower him to how a king, who is ready for battle, would prevail against him. Alternate translation: "just like a king, who is ready for a battle, would prevail against him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a king ready for battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: "as a man does for his neighbor." Job describes how he wants that one in heaven to plead for him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a man does with his neighbor!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Shadows have no thickness and are infinitely thin. That is an exaggeration of how thin Job's body parts are. Alternate translation: "all my body parts are very thin" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: all my body parts are as thin as shadows

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of God causing Job not to have hope as if Job's hope were a tree that God has pulled with its roots out of the ground. Alternate translation: "he has completely taken away all my hope" or "because of what he has done, I can no longer hope for anything good" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: he has pulled up my hope like a tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile is also an ellipsis. You may need to supply the omitted words. Alternate translation: "the way a man pulls a tree up by its roots" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: like a tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: Feces mixes in with the ground and disappears. The reference to feces may also imply that the wicked person is worthless. Alternate translation: "will perish permanently like his feces, which completely disappears in the ground" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: will perish permanently like his own feces

contextId.occurrenceNote: If people are embarrassed about the word feces, translators may refer to something else that disappears completely. Alternate translation: "will disappear permanently like dust that the wind blows away" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: will perish permanently like his own feces

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job compares these children to lambs to emphasize that they run, play, and are happy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: little ones like a flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: The death of the wicked is spoken of as if they were worthless less chaff and stubble that blows away. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "God takes them away like the wind blows away the chaff" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: they become like stubble before the wind or like chaff that the storm carries away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The death of wicked people is compared to buildings that had their foundations washed away by a flood. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: those whose foundations have washed away like a river

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job believes that the test will prove that he is as pure as refined gold. Alternate translation: "he will see that I am as pure as gold when anything not pure has been burned away" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I will come out like gold

contextId.occurrenceNote: These poor people are spoken of as if they are wild donkeys who do not know where they will find food. Alternate translation: "these poor people go out to search for food as if they were wild donkeys in the wilderness" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: these poor people go out to their work like wild donkeys in the wilderness, looking carefully for food

contextId.occurrenceNote: The murderer kills in secret just like a thief steals without anyone seeing what he does. Alternate translation: "he kills people secretly, just like a thief steals secretly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: he is like a thief

contextId.occurrenceNote: The thick darkness is as comfortable for the wicked as light of the morning is for normal people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: For all of them, thick darkness is like the morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Foam lasts only a short time. This emphasizes how quickly God will cause the wicked to disappear. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like foam on the surface of the waters

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job says that sinners will disappear in Sheol in the same way as snow melts and disappears when it becomes warm. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As drought and heat melt away ... those who have sinned

contextId.occurrenceNote: These wicked people will be cut off in the same way heads of grain are cut off during harvest. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "God will cut them off like a farmer cuts off the top of a stalk of grain" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: they will be cut off like the tops of ears of grain

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heaps up" is a metonym meaning "gathers much." Job speaks as if the silver were as easy to get as dust. Alternate translation: "gathers large piles of silver" or "gathers silver as easily as he could gather dust" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: heaps up silver like the dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "heaps up" is a metonym meaning "gathers much." Job speaks as if the clothing were as easy to get as clay. Alternate translation: "gathers large piles of clothing" or "gathers clothing as easily as he could gather clay" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: heaps up clothing like clay

contextId.occurrenceNote: A spider web is fragile and easily destroyed. Alternate translation: "He builds his house as fragile as a spider builds its web" or "He builds his house as fragile as a spider's web" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He builds his house like a spider

contextId.occurrenceNote: A hut is a temporary house that is also not very strong. Alternate translation: "like a temporary hut" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a hut

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "waters" refers to a flood. Floods can happen very suddenly when people do not expect them, and they are dangerous and frightening. Alternate translation: "like a flood" or "like waters that rise up suddenly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like waters

contextId.occurrenceNote: People often spoke of justice as if it were clothing. Alternate translation: "I did what was just, and it was like a robe and a turban on me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: my justice was like a robe and a turban

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "dropped like water on them" represents refreshing the people who heard him. The abstract noun "speech" can be translated with the verb "speak" or "say." Alternate translation: "my speech refreshed their hearts as drops of water refresh people's bodies" or "what I said to them refreshed them like drops of water" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: my speech dropped like water on them

contextId.occurrenceNote: People waited for Job patiently and expected to hear good things. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They always waited for me as they waited for rain

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of how he led the people and how they obeyed him as if he were a king and they were his army. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I lived like a king in his army

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of the men crying out in hunger as if they were wild donkeys making a loud noise. Alternate translation: "cried out like wild donkeys because they were hungry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: brayed like donkeys

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents attacking Job forcefully. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They come against me like an army through a wide hole in a city wall

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of suddenly having no honor as if the wind had blown it from him. Alternate translation: "Nobody honors me" or "I am now a person that people do not honor" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: my honor is driven away as if by the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of his prosperity ending as if it were a cloud that was blown away. Here "prosperity" may refer to well-being or safety. Alternate translation: "I no longer prosper at all" or "I am no longer safe" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: my prosperity passes away as a cloud

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents Job's feeling of being worthless. Alternate translation: "I have become as worthless as dust and ashes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I have become like dust and ashes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means Job would approach God without any fear. Job implies that he could do this because he was not guilty. Alternate translation: "I would approach him boldly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a confident prince I would go up to him

contextId.occurrenceNote: While wine is fermenting, gas collects in the container. If the gas is not let out the container will burst. Elihu means that he has so much to say that if he does not speak he feels like he will burst. Also, these two phrases are parallel and have the same meaning. Alternate translation: "I feel like my breast is about to burst, like a container of fermenting wine that has no vent" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: my breast is like fermenting wine that has no vent; like new wineskins, it is ready to burst

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the man being healed and his body growing strong again as if his body became new like a child's body. Alternate translation: "the sick man's body will become new again like a young person's body" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: his flesh will become fresher than a child's

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu means people listen carefully to determine what is right or wrong just like we taste food to determine if it is good or bad. Here people are referred to by their "ear" and their "palate" to emphasize that they are tasting and hearing. Alternate translation: "For we listen to words to know what is good and bad, just as we taste foods to know what is good to eat" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: For the ear tries words as the palate tastes food

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu is accusing Job of mocking others as often as a person drinks water. Alternate translation: "who mocks other people as frequently as he drinks water" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: who drinks up mockery like water

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase compares the way that these people die to how criminals die. Alternate translation: "He kills them for their wicked deeds, in the open sight of others as if they were criminals" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: In the open sight of others, he kills them for their wicked deeds like criminals

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu compares the hardness of ice to the hardness of metal. Alternate translation: "frozen, as hard as metal" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: frozen like metal

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares his creation of the sea to childbirth. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as if it had come out of the womb

contextId.occurrenceNote: At nighttime, people cannot see clearly, but in the morning the light reveals the distinct shape of everything, just like a seal creates distinct images in clay. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: The earth is changed in appearance like clay changes under a seal

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "it" refers to the earth. This phrase has a similar meaning to the first phrase in this verse. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: all things on it stand out clearly like the folds of a piece of clothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hardness of ice is spoken of as if it was stone. Alternate translation: "become hard like stone" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: become like stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: A man who tucks his robe up under his sash or belt is preparing for hard physical work, and Job was to prepare for the hard work of answering God. See how you translated this in [Job 38:3](../38/03.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: gird up your loins like a man

contextId.occurrenceNote: The arm is a metonym for the strength in the arm. Alternate translation: "strength like God's strength" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: an arm like God's

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both the behemoth and the ox eat grass. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: eats grass like an ox

contextId.occurrenceNote: Cedar is a very hard wood, and his tail becomes very hard. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a cedar

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, his bones are compared to tubes made of bronze to show how tough this animal is. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like tubes of bronze

contextId.occurrenceNote: This last comparison describes the strength of this great animal. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like bars of iron

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that his eyes are red as the morning dawn is red. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning dawn

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both the smoke and a boiling pot are very hot. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: smoke like a boiling pot

contextId.occurrenceNote: A rock or stone does not change and become soft. Possible meanings are 1) Leviathan's physical chest and the organs inside it are physically hard or 2) Leviathan is not afraid of anything or 3) Leviathan is spoken of as a person who kills without ever being sorry. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: His heart is as hard as a stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: "He thinks of weapons made of iron as if they were weapons made of straw." Straw would not get through his hide, and iron weapons do not get through his hide. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He thinks of iron as if it were straw

contextId.occurrenceNote: Just as a threshing sledge goes over grain on a threshing floor and turns it to powder, so Leviathan's tail leaves a trail in the mud as he wags it when he walks. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: he leaves a spreading trail in the mud as if he were a threshing sledge

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ointment in a pot is cloudy if someone shakes it, and the sea is muddy when Leviathan swims in it. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: he makes the sea like a pot of ointment
